document.docAuthor: Hiro, Uchida, omi, Lopéz, Eduardo & Sato, Masanori
document.masterDocTitle: New Hesionidae (Annelida) from Japan: Unavailable Names Introduced by Uchida (2004) Revisited, with Reestablishment of their Availability

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: New Hesionidae (Annelida) from Japan: Unavailable Names Introduced by Uchida (2004) Revisited, with Reestablishment of their Availability

mods:name.mods:affiliation: Department of Biology, Universidad Autónoma de Madrid, C / Darwin 2, Madrid 28049, Spain E-mail: Eduardo. lopez @ uam. es & Corresponding author
Faculty of Science, Kagoshima University, Korimoto, Kagoshima 890 - 0065, Japan

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Ichthyohesione Uchida, 2004: 82
( nomen nudum , without type species fixation);
Ruta et al. 2006: 101
.

subSubSection.paragraph: Diagnosis. Body small, depressed, with few segments. Prostomium embedded into peristomium; with two minute antennae, without palps. Two pairs of tentacular cirri on first segment. Mouth opening at distal margin of prostomium. Proboscis sucker-shaped, with sucking face directed dorsally; without marginal papillae, but with densely ciliated inner surface. Parapodia biramous, with ventral lamellae; notochaetae simple, with serrated edge; neurochaetae compound falcigers.

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 16.
Parahesiocaeca japonica
gen. et sp. nov. , holotype (NSMT-Pol H-761) (E–L) and paratypes (NSMT-Pol P-762) (A–D). A, dorsal view of the anterior body. B, dorsal view of the anterior end with everted proboscis (median antenna and left dorsal tentacular cirrus on the second segment lost). C, ventral view of the anterior end with proboscis not everted. D, ventral view of everted proboscis. E, enlarged ventral view of left side of anterior body, showing two pairs of tentacular cirri and chaetigers 1 and 2 (dorsal and ventral tentacular cirri on the second segment lost). F, dorsal view of the posterior body (left anal cirrus lost). G, posterior view of right parapodium 7. H, notopodial aciculae. I, neuropodial acicula. J, supra-acicular chaeta. K, superior sub-acicular chaeta. L, inferior sub-acicular chaeta. Scale bar: 0.5 mm for A; 0.2 mm for B–D, F; 0.1mm for E, G; 0.02mm for H–L.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type species.
Ichthyohesione gorgasiae
sp. nov. , fixed by original designation.

Etymology. The genus is named after the finding of its symbiotic relationship with a fish, the garden eel (
Gorgasia sp.
, Congridae ).

Remarks. The presence of two pairs of tentacular cirri is a very uncommon condition in Hesionidae . Only a single genus,
Orseis Ehlers, 1864
has been described as having the same number of tentacular cirri, although it possessed three antennae, non-articulated palps, and uniramous parapodia without notochaetae ( Ehlers 1864 ). However, this genus was described based on a single, juvenile specimen and subsequently synonymized with
Oxydromus
by Pleijel (1998) . Two pairs of tentacular cirri also fits within the known intraspecific variability in
Heteropodarke heteromorpha
from Peru ( Hartmann-Schröder 1962a ), but all the species of
Heteropodarke
bear articulated palps and three non-articulated antennae, together with the presence of marginal papillae in the proboscis.

Ichthyohesione gorgasiae Uchida
, sp. nov. [New Japanese name: Uo-tsuki-otohime] ( Figs 17 , 18 )

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Ichthyohesione gorgasiae Uchida, 2004: 82–85
, figs 21, 22 (unavailable specific name, without explicit fixation of name-bearing types ).

paragraph.materialsCitation:
Holotype : (NSMT-Pol H-763), found in the sea water in the vinyl plastic bag used for transporting a garden eel (
Gorgasia taiwanensis Shao, 1990
), collected off Sabiura , Kushimoto , Wakayama Prefecture ( 33º28′51″N , 135°44′45″E ), sandy bottom,
40 m depth
,
17 November 1995
.

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 17.
Ichthyohesione gorgasiae
gen. et sp. nov. , holotype (NSMT-Pol H-763). A, dorsal view of the anterior body with proboscis everted. B, dorsal view of the anterior end with proboscis not everted (a rough sketch in living condition). C, enlarged dorsal view of the anterior end. D, enlarged ventral view of the anterior end (dark violet pigment inside the body shown as dotting). E, dorsal view of the posterior end. F, anterior view of chaetiger 21. Scale bar: 0.2 mm for A, B, E, F; 0.1 mm for C, D.

Fig. 18.
Ichthyohesione gorgasiae
gen. et sp. nov. , holotype (NSMT-Pol H-763). A, posterior view of left parapodium 29. B, anterior view of right parapodium 28. C, tip of notopodial acicula. D, tip of neuropodial postchaetal lobe and tip of acicula. E, notochaeta. F, inferiormost neurochaeta. G, median neurochaeta. H, superiormost neurochaeta. Scale bar: 0.1 mm for A, B; 0.02 mm for C–H.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Etymology. The specific name is a noun in the genitive case of the fish genus
Gorgasia
, which is likely to host it.

Remarks. The detailed description of the type material was presented in Uchida (2004) . Within Hesionidae , the presence of only two pairs of tentacular cirri is extremely rare and no other species showing this trait has the prostomium fused to peristomium and lacking median antenna.

Although common in other annelids ( i.e. , Hirudinea), external parasitism on vertebrates is an extremely rare condition in polychaetous annelids. Thus far, Ichtyotomus
sanguinarius Eisig, 1906
( Ichthyotomidae ) has been known as the only polychaete species symbiotic with a fish, and it is interesting that its host species also belongs to the family Congridae ( Eisig 1906 ;
Culurgioni et al. 2006
) even though the two polychaetes belong to different systematics groups. Both
I. sanguinarius
and the new species are external para- sites, with the prostomium truncated, besides inhabiting very distant geographical areas. The two species are clearly different from each other in the following morphological features: (1)
I. saguinarius
possesses chitinous stylet-shaped mandibles that are used as attachment devices, whereas the new species apparently attaches by means of an anterior sucker, probably aided by modified notopodia. In this way, the new species might behave as
Calamyzas amphictenicola Arwidsson, 1932
( Chrysopetalidae , Calamyzinae), which lives as an ectoparasite on ampharetid polychaetes in Swedish waters ( Arwidsson 1932 ;
Aguado et al. 2013
) attaching to them by means of an oral sucker; (2) the parapodia of
I. sanguinarius
are subbiramous with notoacicula but lacking notochaetae, whereas those of the new species are biramous; and (3) the compound neurochaetae of
I. sanguinarius
have highly modified blades being long and smooth or very short and dentate, in contrast to those of the new species with typical hesionid blades.
